Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, calculator in hand, staring at the numbers that refused to add up. The home loan repayment loomed just two months away, and every cent mattered. As a parent, I felt the weight of ensuring my family’s security, of keeping a roof over our heads. My phone buzzed—a reminder for tomorrow’s court session. As an advocate, my presence at this high-stakes proceeding was non-negotiable; my client’s future could hinge on my punctuality and focus. But the meeting was scheduled at the same time as a call with the bank manager, the only slot available to negotiate a possible extension on the loan. My mind raced with the expectations pressing in from both sides: my family counting on me to keep us afloat, my client relying on my expertise and commitment. Anxiety twisted in my chest as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once, knowing that failing in either role could have consequences I wasn’t ready to face.
